subject: Re: JUnit report for multiple runs of a single class
msgSnippet: Thanks!  This is where a work around could work.  However, I have another issue.  I ve never been very good with regular expressions, which seems to be the

Thanks!  This is where a work around could work.  However, I have 
another issue.  I've never been very good with regular expressions, 
which seems to be the best way to either search and replace or search 
and add.  If I have a project class and I want to add a name, what 
would I do?  Here's a vague example of what I'm trying to do:

<testsuite ... name="[package name].class" ...> changed to:
<testsuite ... name="[package name].class.[test name]" ...>

Because the package name (or similarly class name) is the same for 
every test, the test was overwritten.  However, each test I run has 
it's own name, which I could add at the end as described above.  The 
only bad part is that the report then recognizes the "[package 
name].class" as the package, instead of just the package and the 
test "[test name]" as the class instead of the actual class.  This is 
more of an annoyance, however, not an actual problem.

If someone has any pointers on good ways to use reg ex or another 
method, I'd appreciate it.  I hope to be able to do this for multiple 
files, so I'm looking for a more script-like implementation.  I 
understand I could use "sed" in Unix, but again, I am not very good 
with regular expressions.  Thanks!




--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
> junit_rinaldi wrote:
> 
> > In general, the output shows that there were a certain number of
> > tests, but because the same class is used, the <class>.html file 
is
> > overwritten along with other helpful output information.  This 
leaves
> > only the output for the last test run.
> > 
> > If anyone knows a good method for getting around this JUnit
> > limitation, please let me know!!!
> 
> Play around with test suite and test case /names/, since I believe 
> /those/ are used to generate report files, and not class names. The 
> coincidence is that, by default, test suites and test cases are 
named 
> after their respective class/method names. You can always change 
the 
> name of a test suite, although at present I only know of one way to 
do it:
> 
> suite = new TestSuite("My Custom-Named Test Suite");
> 
> I suggest looking at how to change the /names/ of the various Test 
> objects (suites and cases) to get the desired result.
> 
> Good luck.
> -- 
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand
